image.altText: Mike Pezzullo holds his hands in the air as he sits at a desk inside a Parliament House committee room

props.synopsis: The secretary of the Home Affairs Department, Mike Pezzullo, is asked to step down as an investigation is conducted into text messages he is alleged to have sent to a Liberal Party powerbroker.

title.children: Home Affairs secretary Mike Pezzullo stood aside after alleged texts to Liberal powerbroker

image.altText: Two people holding hands in a hospital.

props.synopsis: The case, detailed in the first annual report by the Voluntary Assisted Dying (VAD) Review Board, is the subject of review by Queensland Health.

title.children: Investigation launched into death of man who took voluntary assisted dying drug prescribed for someone else

image.altText: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers speaking to media

props.synopsis: The federal government releases new definition of "full employment" to reflect a modern labour market, saying it needs to be conscious of underemployment.

title.children: 'Full employment' will be redefined to reflect modern labour market, the Employment White Paper has found

image.altText: Tasha Jordan and Ken Belbin standing next to the Golden Homes sign.

props.synopsis: Two families who sank their life savings into building their dream homes are unable to move in, with one family left living in a shed and the other couch-surfing.

title.children: 'An interesting form of construction!': Surveyors say that Tasha's home is not built to code, but no-one will fix it

image.altText: A woman sits in the passenger seat of a car, looking to one side with a serious expression. The windows have rain drops on them.

props.synopsis: People living with disabilities are being coerced into rented accommodation by unscrupulous operators who can drain their NDIS funding and leave them with little, if any, support.

title.children: This nurse has had to rescue clients 'abducted' by unscrupulous NDIS providers

image.altText: Carter Gordon kicks the ball

props.synopsis: Eddie Jones fixed a journalist with an icy stare and denied any knowledge of reports he spoke to Japan officials about taking the Cherry Blossoms head coaching gig, saying he was committed to the Wallabies role following the harrowing World Cup defeat to Wales.

title.children: Eddie Jones stands by his decision to sack Wallabies veterans despite World Cup humiliation at hands of Wales

image.altText: Two men in wetsuits fist pump the air with glee at the beach

props.synopsis: When Aussie rock band Silverchair broke up in 2011, drummer Ben Gillies was left feeling sad, heavy and unsure where to turn. Then he had a frightening anxiety attack while in the surf. This is how he staged a life comeback.

title.children: Silverchair drummer Ben Gillies reveals the ultimatum that would change his life after the band collapsed

image.altText: A woman pushes Natasha Fyles with one hand and pushes a paper plate into her face with the other hand

props.synopsis: Natasha Fyles says she is "in a bit of pain" after she was allegedly "given a good whack" with a cream-covered pancake on Sunday. It comes after police charged a 56-year-old woman with aggravated assault over the attack.

title.children: NT chief minister reports pain, bruising after alleged pancake attack, as police review security

image.altText: A dark-grey capsule with a yellow port sits on the ground in the desert.

props.synopsis: A NASA space capsule carrying the largest soil samples ever scooped up from the surface of an asteroid streaks through Earth's atmosphere and parachutes into the Utah desert.

title.children: 'Really historic' asteroid sample returned to Earth as NASA eyes the future

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a red dress and long red gloves, looking away from the camera with hand on hip and longish blonde hair

props.synopsis: With a new album, the anthem of the year and a major Las Vegas residency, Kylie Minogue is as unstoppable as ever. So how does she keep doing it again and again? The Australian superstar shares that and more while speaking with ABC News Breakfast.

title.children: Kylie Minogue holds the crown as Queen of pop and the dance floor with another megahit single out

image.altText: A large section of forested land juts out from the ocean.

props.synopsis: Police say the accident highlights the need for more caution when taking tourist photos.

title.children: Public safety warning follows woman's Phillip Island selfie plunge

image.altText: Chinese tourists posing to camera in the Blue Mountains.

props.synopsis: From today, the Australian government will restart the visa process for Chinese group travellers in what is expected to be a major boost to Australian tourism.

title.children: Chinese tourists return at a fast rate, but do we have enough flights and tour guides to serve them?

image.altText: A drone shot shows suburban blocks in South Auckland.

props.synopsis: In Auckland, the council has been running an experiment, and at the heart of it is a bold decision to remove restrictions around zoning — but the New Zealand election could change things.

title.children: Australia has long debated this housing idea, but in Auckland it's already working

image.altText: A Carlton AFL player stands on stage with a medal around his neck, and a sign behind him with the image of the Brownlow Medal.

props.synopsis: The AFL's highest individual award, the Brownlow Medal, will be awarded to the league's best and fairest player of the 2023 season. Here's everything you need to know.

title.children: Everything you need to know about this year's Brownlow Medal

image.altText: A well-lit street filled with cars and people at night.

props.synopsis: The Nagorno-Karabakh region's leadership says 120,000 Armenians do not want to live as part of Azerbaijan for fear of persecution and ethnic cleansing.

title.children: Armenians begin leaving Azerbaijan en masse after 'iron fist' ends Soviet-era civil conflict

image.altText: Two men in military uniforms inspect a half-built classroom.

props.synopsis: Months after an expected date to sign a Bilateral Security Treaty, Australia and PNG remain at the negotiating table, working to create a framework for current defence activities as well as expanded security cooperation in the future.

title.children: PNG and Australia's defence cooperation is a 'jewel' of their relationship but forming a treaty has not been simple

image.altText: Samu Kerevi holds his face

props.synopsis: The Wallabies fall to a record-breaking Rugby World Cup defeat against Wales, falling into old traps and making crucial errors of judgement. Here are the five key moments from an embarrassing defeat in Lyon.

title.children: Five quick hits — An opening-minute blunder and a final-minute fan exodus as Wallabies hit World Cup low

image.altText: A male ballet dancing in a brown shirt and green tights posing on stage.

props.synopsis: Rural Queensland is a far cry from the Romanian theatres he is used to, but Douglas Stewart is determined to make sure country kids have as much access to dance as they do to sport.

title.children: After Douglas's career in Romania hit a wall, he started teaching country kids ballet. He hasn't looked back

image.altText: Qantas planes sit parked at Sydney Airport, with the city's skyline in the background.

props.synopsis: When a customer advocate is described as feckless and a dud it should be a clarion call to fix it. Two years after the Aviation Consumer Advocate was labelled a "shonky impostor", things are finally heating up, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: The 'shonky impostor' that's meant to help with your airline complaints

image.altText: A police officer in a balaclava holding a rifle patrols a road in front of a white angel statue.

props.synopsis: Kosovan police said one officer and three attackers died in shootouts around the village of Banjska before forcing entry to the monastery.

title.children: Four dead in northern Kosovo as gunmen battle police, barricade themselves in monastery

image.altText: A young man holding a phone showing a map of Sydney

props.synopsis: The software engineer says the more time people spend waiting for the green person to flash, the less inclined they feel to walk or cycle, which is "not a great outcome".

title.children: What's the longest time you've spent waiting to cross the road in Sydney? Jake wants to know

image.altText: Composite image Steve Fisher 2003 and 2023

props.synopsis: Twenty years ago, Steve Fisher became the first person in Tasmania to win the legal right to identify himself as a victim-survivor of child sexual abuse. Now, with a groundbreaking report to be handed down this week, he says the reckoning has only just begun.

title.children: 'I'm a victim of Garth Hawkins': 20 years ago, Steve had to fight in court to identify himself

image.altText: Usher, wearing sunglasses and a light pink jacket and pants, smiles as he sings into a microphone on stage.

props.synopsis: Eight-time Grammy Award-winner Usher will headline the Super Bowl LVIII half-time show and he wants to "socially engage the world" to hear which stars should join him on stage.

title.children: Keeping secrets 'from my own kids': Usher revealed as the 2024 Super Bowl half-time show headliner

image.altText: Sepia coloured photo of army man and bride is pastel blue

props.synopsis: Some Aussies boarded "bride ships" to America to live with their husbands, while others stayed behind, worried they may never return.

title.children: Thousands of Aussie women wed US troops during World War II. But there was a common deal-breaker

image.altText: hands hold colourful leaflets that read Tes 23

props.synopsis: Two big ethical questions have emerged during the Voice to Parliament campaign: is it fair that non-Indigenous people will get the majority say? And is it fair if one group will get something others don't? Paul Formosa explains.

title.children: Is it ethical that non-Indigenous people get to decide on the Voice? An ethicist explains

image.altText: Chinese Coast Guard boats close to the floating barrie

props.synopsis: The Philippines says the floating barrier prevents Filipino fishermen from entering and fishing in the contested Scarborough Shoal.

title.children: China accused of erecting new barrier near disputed South China Sea shoal

image.altText: A night time photo of a Queensland Police Service car with its blue light illuminated.

props.synopsis: Police say a 44-year-old man came to the Fortitude Valley Police Station on Sunday afternoon with a knife wound to his abdomen before being taken to the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital in a critical condition.

title.children: Woman charged with attempted murder in Brisbane

image.altText: Close-up image of Olivia Rodrigo biting her thumb, next to image of Miley Cyrus  twerking next to Robin Thick on stage.

props.synopsis: Former Disney star Olivia Rodrigo is the same age Miley Cyrus was when her VMAs performance saw her publicly vilified and scolded. So with Olivia's new album GUTS already a hit, have times changed in the decade since Miley-gate?

title.children: From Blurred Lines to a girl with GUTS: How Olivia Rodrigo may avoid the Miley treatment

image.altText: Ancient looking skeletons on display

props.synopsis: Researchers say a newly-named species of prehistoric crocodile that once roamed central Australia "would've eaten whatever it wanted".

title.children: Eight-million-year-old outback predator named in honour of its hunting prowess

image.altText: Australia batter David Warner falls as he is dismissed in an ODI against India.

props.synopsis: Australia loses a fifth straight ODI on World Cup eve, not getting close to India's 399 at a rain-soaked Indore Stadium.

title.children: David Warner's bizarre dismissal and Cameron Green's horror night sum up ODI thumping by India

image.altText: A dark and blurred image of a woman looking into a mirror

props.synopsis: With black eyes, bruised arms, and threatened with a shot gun, Kate knew she had to leave a violent relationship on a farm in rural Western Australia. But she faced a big question — how?

title.children: 'I'm going to bury you alive': Domestic violence survivor speaks out after ex-partner sentenced

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

props.synopsis: The federal government has released its Employment White Paper after a year-long consultation that will pave the way for future jobs and skills in Australia, while the ASX has opened lower after Wall Street fell on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: 'Very important day' as government releases Employment White Paper, Qantas to spend $80m on customer 'pain points', ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says redefining "full employment" comes down to a "couple of considerations". "What the Employment White Paper tries to do is to say that when we consider full employment, it needs to be a much broader conception than what we've had in the past," he said. "There is a really important, necessary but essentially narrow and technical definition of full employment than not only exhilarating inflation rate of unemployment but distinct from that and complementary to that, it's the government's objective, which is a good, secure, fairly paid job for everyone who wants one without having to look for too long. "That is our goal and that's our objective that sits alongside, it doesn't contradict, compliments the shorter term definitions that people like the Reserve Bank and Treasury use to drive their assumptions." He says broadening the scope of what defines "full employment" has benefits for both the short and long-term. "The near term and longer term and all the other issues that we've talked about shouldn't beyond us, not just to deal with the skills shortages in our economy right now but also to make sure that we are anticipating and positioning our people to be major beneficiaries of the big changes that we anticipate in our economy and our society," he said. "If we get this right, if we get the right working future for people in our economy, then that will give us every chance of making this a defining decade, a decade that we can look back on and be proud that we took the sorts of steps which are outlined in this White Paper." And with that, the press conference about the government's White Paper has concluded.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How does the Treasurer define 'full employment' now?

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says redefining "full employment" comes down to a "couple of considerations".
"What the Employment White Paper tries to do is to say that when we consider full employment, it needs to be a much broader conception than what we've had in the past," he said.

"There is a really important, necessary but essentially narrow and technical definition of full employment than not only exhilarating inflation rate of unemployment but distinct from that and complementary to that, it's the government's objective, which is a good, secure, fairly paid job for everyone who wants one without having to look for too long.

"That is our goal and that's our objective that sits alongside, it doesn't contradict, compliments the shorter term definitions that people like the Reserve Bank and Treasury use to drive their assumptions."
He says broadening the scope of what defines "full employment" has benefits for both the short and long-term.

"The near term and longer term and all the other issues that we've talked about shouldn't beyond us, not just to deal with the skills shortages in our economy right now but also to make sure that we are anticipating and positioning our people to be major beneficiaries of the big changes that we anticipate in our economy and our society," he said.

"If we get this right, if we get the right working future for people in our economy, then that will give us every chance of making this a defining decade, a decade that we can look back on and be proud that we took the sorts of steps which are outlined in this White Paper."
And with that, the press conference about the government's White Paper has concluded.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's how Education Minister Jason Clare responded to that question: "Six universities in Australia are dual sector universities, running TAFE courses and university courses at the same time," he said. "One of the ideas in the report is a tertiary education system to help bring the two sectors closer together, among other centres of excellence where you put them under the one roof, also there are ideas about how do you create a course which is a mixture of the two. "These higher apprenticeship degrees are one way to do that when you get that university level education with that practical experience embedded in. "I think when you look at the work rendered is doing with the Skills Agreement and the Universities Accord, there is a common theme that is coming out of that, nine out of 10 jobs that will be created in the next 10 years will require you to either go to TAFE or university. "It is not just the one course you do at TAFE or one course you do at university, it will involve up skilling and reskilling as well so that gets added on, that is why the idea of a skills passport as important as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are universities comfortable with bachelor's degrees being provided by TAFE?

children.content: Here's how
Education Minister Jason Clare
responded to that question:
"Six universities in Australia are dual sector universities, running TAFE courses and university courses at the same time," he said.

"One of the ideas in the report is a tertiary education system to help bring the two sectors closer together, among other centres of excellence where you put them under the one roof, also there are ideas about how do you create a course which is a mixture of the two.
"These higher apprenticeship degrees are one way to do that when you get that university level education with that practical experience embedded in.

"I think when you look at the work rendered is doing with the Skills Agreement and the Universities Accord, there is a common theme that is coming out of that, nine out of 10 jobs that will be created in the next 10 years will require you to either go to TAFE or university.

"It is not just the one course you do at TAFE or one course you do at university, it will involve up skilling and reskilling as well so that gets added on, that is why the idea of a skills passport as important as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Amanda Rishworth responded to this question from a reporter: "What we have put forward is innovative, because what it allows pensioners to do is not necessarily work on a regular basis, but supports them to take up seasonal or other ad hoc opportunities," she said. "That is what pensioners have told us they are interested in doing and of course we need to recognise that a lot of pensioners, when they reach pension age do not want to work, what our design has been is about allowing for as much flexibility as possible, and supporting pensioners in a range of ad hoc arrangements, part-time or potentially seasonal work, which is what pensioners have said they are most interested in participating. "Of course, the other element ... is when somebody reaches their retirement age, is actually the time when we have seen most likely pensioners take up the opportunity to work a little more, they may still have a certificate or training that is current and so would like to continue to do some work and that is what our announcement about the upfront amount on their income bank is all about. "We believe we have got the settings right, we believe this is the right settings to support pensioners moving to work and ensure their work patterns are supported."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the $11,800 enough for pensioners moving into work?

children.content: Amanda Rishworth responded to this question from a reporter:

"What we have put forward is innovative, because what it allows pensioners to do is not necessarily work on a regular basis, but supports them to take up seasonal or other ad hoc opportunities," she said.

"That is what pensioners have told us they are interested in doing and of course we need to recognise that a lot of pensioners, when they reach pension age do not want to work, what our design has been is about allowing for as much flexibility as possible, and supporting pensioners in a range of ad hoc arrangements, part-time or potentially seasonal work, which is what pensioners have said they are most interested in participating.
"Of course, the other element ...

is when somebody reaches their retirement age, is actually the time when we have seen most likely pensioners take up the opportunity to work a little more, they may still have a certificate or training that is current and so would like to continue to do some work and that is what our announcement about the upfront amount on their income bank is all about.
"We believe we have got the settings right, we believe this is the right settings to support pensioners moving to work and ensure their work patterns are supported."

image.altText: A picture of a smiling young boy and his mother

props.synopsis: Jane Jones felt grief and loss when her son Zac was jailed. They've written a book about the experience to help other parents deal with having a child behind bars.

title.children: There was no support for Jane when her son was imprisoned. Now she's using her experience to help others
